ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: By taking this course, I was able to learn about documentary as both a concept of film and as a technique. I was able to learn the different aspects of film that are included specifically in documentaries and the many different purposes that documentary filmmaking can achieve. On a skill-based level, I learned more about lighting, sound, and the art of the interview and how to use all of those aspects to achieve a good documentary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course is its amount of engagement and hands-on learning because that was the best way to learn the materials and get constructive criticism from any mistakes. I'm not entirely sure about a weakness for this class, the professor was great in making sure the class went well.

Strengths: Love Professor Steiner! The class environment was fun and uplifting. I really liked watching other students' work. 

Weakness: The class is wayyyy too long. Nearly 4 hours. And most days it did go until the last minute. Some of the docs we watched were really long and experimental. The readings were also pretty niche.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if they have any interest in film because it is a really great way to explore that interest in an incredibly safe and productive learning space where everyone's progress is supported. It's also just a fun class where you can freely express your creativity.

Well, it depends. If you're into documentary theory, then yes. If you have a documentary idea in mind and want some way to execute it, then sure. But otherwise, I would proceed with caution. The class is extremely long and can be really draining if you're not super interested in the content. The readings are similarly long. Steiner is great! I just wish this class was split into two days, so it didn't have to be 4 hours long.
